A schoolboy basketball double feature at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon enlisted the earnest and vociferous attention of some 3,000 spectators, a majority of them youthful supporters of the four teams involved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)-- James F. Byrnes said today that the ban on racing had saved 19,000 miles of leased wire circuits.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 21 (AP)-- John Warren Davis Sr., retired judge of the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia and formerly Federal District Judge of New Jersey, died today at Norfolk Hospital, at the age of 77. He was taken ill recently at his farm in Princess Anne County.

Henri Bonnet, French Ambas-- sador to the United States, declared last night at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that the people of France wish to see the German problem solved so that Prussian militarism may not again imperil the welfare and liberty of Europe.
A complete review of the spring collection of one house of design was shown yesterday noon in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre, by Sada Saks, specialty shop of 671 Madison Avenue.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 2,225,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies of civilian grade of gasoline were up 1,383,000 barrels to 49,265,000 at the close of the period and military and other grades rose 842,000 to 45,415,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)--A reorganization plan for the Rutland Railroad, which operates in Vermont and New York State, was submitted today to the Interstate Commerce Commission. It calls for new capitalization of $12,084,684. Present holders of common stock would be disregarded.

Actual transfer of the Yankees to their new owners was effected yesterday at the Manufacturers Trust Company, 55 Broad Street.

The New York Life Insurance Company had $7,644,703,000 of insurance in force in 3,292,584 policies at the end of 1944, according to the 100th annual report, to be published today. This represents a gain of $304,121,686 over the previous year and was the largest increase in any year since 1930.

McGowan, Democrat of Manhattan, offered today a bill which would stay evictions until six months after the war.

Increased markets for American goods in France and resumption of large-scale French exports to this country depend upon the speed with which we aid the liberated country in her economic recovery by sending her commodities indispensable to achieve that goal, Henri Bonnet, French Ambassador to the United States, indicated last night.

PARIS, Feb, 21 (Delayed)--The first small step toward the reeducation of Nazi Germany is being made at Aachen, Allied officials stated today, with the printing of 20,000 new German school books under the military government's supervision.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--A young naval reserve officer, prisoner of the Japanese since Corregidor fell in May, 1942, calmly told today of how the sinking last Dec. 15 of a Japanese prison ship, on which 800 Americans lost their lives, was a blessing because the American bombs actually saved more of the prisoners from suffocating in the jammed, airless holds.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)-- Army and Navy casualties since the Pearl Harbor attack have reached 801,162.

The eighteen employes of the Metropolitan Tool Works walked up seven flights of stairs yesterday and worked all day in an unheated shop at 247 Centre Street, producing items vitally needed by the Navy. Two workers for the Gross Radio Company hiked six floors to an equally cold and damp shop at 8 West Eighteenth Street to help meet another Navy contract.

LONDON, Feb. 22--Organized world labor today demanded a voice in shaping the peace. Acting on behalf of the World Trade Union Conference, a special committee formulated a message to all the peoples pledging support to the armed forces of the United Nations "in the battles still to be fought to secure full and final victory."

The fourth bout in the series between Ray Robinson, Harlem welterweight, and Jake La Motta of the Bronx will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight. These rivals are slated to travel over the ten-round route, and their meeting is expected to attract a crowd of 15,000 fans. Promoter Mike Jacobs is hopeful that the gate will exceed $60,000.

Business in the Broadway theatres yesterday afternoon was swell, proving once more that Washington's Birthday is the bonanza matinee day of the year. The hits were sold out long in advance so hundreds of theatregoers had to be turned away.

The battle for the volcanic island of Iwo, 750 miles north of Saipan and a like distance south of Tokyo, continues to proceed in the bloody pattern that was set at Tarawa, Kwajalein, Saipan and Guam. The Japanese garrison, now estimated to number perhaps as many as 20,000 men, is going to fight to the last survivor.

Housewives doing their marketing rounds this week-end will find inviting baskets of Florida strawberries available in many fruit stores. They are not the most thrifty purchase, costing in the vicinity of 45 cents a pint, but the War Food Administration reports them of excellent quality. Receipts have been fairly ample so far this week.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 22-- The registered owner, and not the beneficial owner of shares endorsed in blank, is the actual stockholder in a Delaware corporation, the Delaware Supreme Court has ruled in a case involving a merger.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The War Production Board has prepared, at the request of Secretary Harold Ickes, a list of users of coal in terms of their essentiality for application as a guide for granting priorities if a critical shortage forces an outright ban against some consumers of solid fuel.

A lead of two goals failed to hold up for the New York Rovers in their Eastern Hockey League game against the Baltimore Blades at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The local outfit jumped ahead of their rivals by this margin before the second period was three minutes old, but the visitors flashed enough strength to close fast and skate off with a 6-to-4 triumph.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--Nations of the world should make a pact reducing the price of press transmission so that newspapers everywhere could enjoy the privilege of using world-wide news, Senator Ernest W. McFarland of Arizona said in a Senate speech today.

MANILA, Feb. 22--The American Army in Manila is composed of tired men, and not all of them are in the front lines. The emergency problems of Manila are many, and none is busier or more fatigued than the engineers, military police and relief administrators.

Things looked fine for the Rangers when they scored four goals in the first period of their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night and this prospect remained just as bright through the middle frame, as the Blue Shirts held the Red Wings scoreless despite the fact that they failed to hit the cords themselves.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22--The Office of Price Administration placed today new ceilings on wholesalers' and manufacturers' sales of new synthetic rubber soles and heels sold for the shoe repair trade, and simultaneously established an adjusted manufacturer's maximum price for "junior" size synthetic rubber heels used in the production of new shoes.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28--William M. Hickey, president of the United Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today at a hearing on that holding company's second plan to exchange portfolio securities for a certain number of its outstanding $3 preference shares that United expects to continue in business as an investment company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Officials of 104 national organizations were told today by Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, that the Bretton Woods proposals were designed to "bring order to the jungle growth of international financial transactions." The old gold standard, he maintained, could not achieve its former objectives.

MANILA, Thursday, March 1 (UP)--General MacArthur announced today that at the northern end of the Luzon front, where the Americans are battling into the Caraballo Mountains, there is stiff opposition. Troops of the Twenty-fifth Division, which captured Carranglan, eighty miles north of Manila, repulsed a Japanese counter-attack.
ROME, Feb. 28--The first reports have come down from the front indicating that graduates of the infantry conversion center not far from Rome have gone into action and done well.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, is prepared to lay before the soft coal industry demands for a new contract which some operators estimate would total $1.15 to $1.50 per day and cost 20 to 28 cents per ton, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--There is a broad gap existing between policies announced by war agencies for relaxation of restrictions to facilitate re-establishment of veterans in business and the putting into effect of such policies so that many veterans are questioning the integrity of the promises made to them.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The following announcement was issued today by the War Damage Corporation, a subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation:

Plans for five large post-war public housing projects in the city will be on the calendar of the Board of Estimate for approval today, Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, announced yesterday.

When Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's merits and demerits are next totted up, one item in the reckoning should be the statement of W.H. Donald, made in Luzon, that the Generalisgimo indignantly refused at least twelve Japanese peace offers between 1938 and 1940.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--President Roosevelt returned to the White House today, making clear his determination to play an active personal role in the implementation of the steps toward an enduring peace taken in concert with Prime Minister Churchill and Marshal Stalin at the Yalta conference.

GUAM, Thursday, March 1--The beach at Iwo was tougher than Salerno, generally regarded as the hardest landing made in the European area, according to William Goadby Lawrence, New York artist, who won a Silver Star for heroism at Salerno and who told correspondents today how it was at Iwo.

In a statement sent to Assemolyman D. Mallory Stephens, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Rent Control, the Citizens Union yesterday urged adoption of the proposal to extend trade rent ceilings to cover "offices, stores and other commercial space not now protected."

CALCAR, Germany, Feb. 28-- This important railroad junction on the British-Canadian sector between the Meuse [Maas] and Rhine Rivers with a peacetime population of 10,000, has fallen with only a few shots.

The illusion of a comprehensive historial tour of notable American interiors dating from seventeenth century New England to contemporary California was created by the presentation of "three-dimensional" pictures of the "James Ward Thorne American Rooms in Miniature," previewed yesterday afternoon at W. Sloane.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Among 4,449 Army and 152 Navy casualties announced today by the War and Navy Departments, all based upon prior notification to next of kin, were the following (the name following the casualty is that of the next of kin):

GUAM, Thursday, March 1--The Japanese defenders in Iwo Island are being pushed back at a faster rate and the clean-up of the island is now in sight, but there is no indication of a lessening of the toll of American lives that will be sacrificed before the island bastion on the road to Tokyo has fallen.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The War Production Board today extended another ninety days its ban on spot reconversion in laborshort areas.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 28-- President Getulio Vargas today signed a decree amending the Constitution of Nov. 10, 1937, directing that general elections be called but leaving to Congress, when elected, the choice of modifying the present Constitution or creating a new one.

Continuation of the British War Relief Society in a new form after victory in Europe to preserve and extend the feeling of friendship and understanding between the United States and Great Britain was urged yesterday by Sir Robert Appleby, vice president of the society in this country.

ROME, Feb. 28 (AP)--Ten persons, including three officers of Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark's staff, were killed Feb. 19 while en route home on leave when their transport plane crashed on taking off from an Italian field, it was disclosed today. The plane fell 400 feet.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28-- The reported cost of salable property declared surplus through Jan. 31 amounted to $444,096,000, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported today.

ALBANY, Feb. 28--Voting down Democratic amendments one after the other, the Assembly, in full control of the Republicans, approved Governor Dewey's budget program tonight in substantially the same form as he submitted it.
In case you have forgotten how good the Federal Theatre was, a visit to the revival of "Frankie and Johnny" by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the City Center is in order.

The American Tobacco Company and consolidated subsidiaries last year transacted the largest volume of business in its history with sales of $533,373,786 exceeding the 1943 total by $3,951,684, the annual report of George W. Hill, president, disclosed today to stockholders.

LONDON, Thursday, March 1-- Russian troops yesterday seized the five-way rail hub of Neustettin in Pomerania, killing 3,000 of its garrison and gaining five to six miles in their offensive aimed at isolating the Germans in the Baltic coastal area of Danzig, the "Polish Corridor" and northeast Pomerania.

The impression carried away from the collection of custom-made costumes designed by Sophie and presented in the Salon Moderne yesterday afternoon was that they were wearable, every one of them. The National Refugee Service, which has shared heretofore in funds raised by the United Jewish Appeal, announced yesterday that it was undertaking a separate campaign to raise $1,444,330 for refugees in the United States.

ALBANY, Feb. 28--The Assembly passed the Ives-Quinn antidiscrimination bill today by a vote of 109 to 32, after a debate lasting six hours and fifteen minutes during which three proposed amendments were rejected. The vote on the amendments was substantially the same as on final passage.

ABOARD PRESIDENTAL CRUISER IN THE ATLANTIC, Feb. 27 (Delayed)--President Roosevelt divided his traveling to the Crimean conference between warship and plane and returned to American waters without a single close call.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Army's first jet-propelled combat plane, the P-80 Shooting Star, believed to be "the fastest fighter in existence," was announced today by Gen. H. H. Arnold, Army Air Forces Chief. It is described as a fighter of extreme speed, maneuverability and outstanding range.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 (AP)--Lieut. Col. Richard E. Hanley of the Marine Aviation Corps, one-time head football coach at Northwestern University, today signed a three-year post-war contract as head coach and general manager of the Chicago club in the proposed All-America Football Conference.

A Gasoline Industry Rationing Board, to help 10,000 dealers in the New York metropolitan area with their trade and rationing problems, was appointed yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration.

The mere apprehension that interest rates would be lowered on future Treasury financing brought about last month a rising market for Government bonds, according to the March review of credit and business conditions of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WITH UNITED STATES FIELD ARTILLERY on the Cologne Plain, Feb. 27 (Delayed) (U.P.)--Pvt. Donald P. Slevin of the Bronx, New York, pulled the lanyard of a big field piece at 12:30 A.M., today. A minute and a half later the first artillery shell of the war screamed into Cologne, largest German city yet brought under direct fire by the Allies. The whimsical doughboys chalked the name "Eau de Cologne" on the shell, a 95pounder.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in February was the second largest since June and the heaviest for a corresponding month and period since 1937, despite the smaller number of trading sessions.

Closer cooperation between educators and the press to help create an informed public opinion and reduce some of the existing "dangerous ignorance" in this country was urged yesterday by Lester Markel, Sunday editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP)--Dartmouth College "will join in no ban against basketball contests in Gardens," Bill McCarter, director of athletics at the Hanover, N.H., college, asserted today.

The Red Cross 1945 War Fund drive in New York City, with a quota of $21,187,000--more than 10 per cent of the $200,000,000 national goal--will be opened formally at noon today by the chairman, Walter L. (Red) Barber in front of a giant three-dimensional red cross erected in Rockefeller Center between the British Empire and French Buildings.

Undisputed possession of fourth place in the National Hockey League standing will be the objective of the Rangers when they take to the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight in their ninth clash of the season against the Black Hawks.

The removal of License Commissioner Paul Moss because of his forced closing of "Trio" last Saturday was urged yesterday by the Authors League of America in a telegram sent to Mayor La Guardia, as protests against the commissioner's action continued to mount.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 28-- Sportsmen from various sections of the State discussed a proposed conservation exhibit in Bronx Park embracing all phases of the work, the ever-current pheasant situation, the 1945 deer season, hunting and fishing licenses for the armed forces and for women and various other aspects of the outdoors picture at a public hearing on pending conservation bills in the Senate chamber today.

The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday for 1944 a net income of $8,932,994 after charges, taxes and a reserve of $1,000,000 for contingencies arising from the war, equal to $1.91 each on the 4,666,270 shares of capital stock outstanding.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Wage increases of $2 to $4 a week were awarded to 21,250 telephone employes in New York City, Washington, Louisville and Memphis today by the War Labor Board.
Since Wednesday of last week Broadway hasn't had an opening, and this state of affairs will not be remedied until next Wednesday. On that evening "Calico Wedding" will come to the National.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- President Roosevelt told 1,700,000 farm youths today that with final victory still to be attained they must pursue their seven wartime goals "with even more momentum." His letter was in recognition of National 4-H Club Week opening Saturday.

The war moves toward its furious climax. The casualty lists lengthen relentlessly. There can be no turning back now for the millions of our youth engulfed in the conflict. Nor can we at home allow any weakening of our determination to do everything humanly possible for them in their supreme hour of sacrifice.

It took a long time, but the N.Y.U. basketball team, after so many disappointments, finally lived up to its potentialities. Last night at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 17,341 fans Howard Cann's Violets ran wild at the expense of a pretty fair Temple University outfit, speeding to an 85-54 victory that completely won the fancy of the spectators.

Arnold Constable's show, held yesterday noon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, was divided into five groups dealing with the spring and summed needs of a wide feminine age group. PARIS, Feb. 28--After having heard Foreign Minister Georges Bidault report on his week-end talks in London, the French Cabinet decided today to accept a position among the inviting powers for the San Francisco meeting of the United Nations, but on the understanding that this role would not prevent France from proposing amendments to the Dumbarton Oaks project.

With the naming yesterday of 678 elementary school teachers to fill openings, the Board of Education brought to 2,260 its appointments in the last fifteen months and thus in that period approved a larger list than it had in the previous fifteen years.
The nation's gasoline stocks increased 1,292,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Companions of President Roosevelt on his 14,000-mile round trip to the Yalta Conference were unanimous today in the view that except for a slight cold on the outward journey his health was excellent. This was borne out by Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, his personal physician, who accompanied him on his travels.

With Representative A. Clayton Powell Jr. characterizing confirmation of Henry A. Wallace for Secretary of Commerce as the first step toward electing him President in 1948, trade union leaders and delegates of the American Labor party adopted last night a resolution urging the Senate to confirm Mr. Wallace without further delay.

LONDON, Feb. 28--Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the German Propaganda Minister, who has emerged as one of the two strongest figures of Germany's dying days, declared tonight that, despite the fast-moving Red Army and the "inhuman proportions" of the Allies' "air terror," Germany would resist to the end and even win back the territory that she had lost.

The National Shoe Manufacturers Association expressed yesterday serious concern over the workshoe situation because of the large amount of side leather channeled into military and juvenile footwear, and heavy military demands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Maj. Gen. Edwin M. Watson, military aide and secretary to President Roosevelt, was buried with military honors in Arlington Cemetery today while the President, his close friend for many years, looked on during a fall of rain and sleet. General Watson died at sea on Feb. 20 while returning with the President from the Yalta conference.

John J. Lyons, former Secretary of State of the State of New York, and more recently one of the proprietors of Lyons Chop House, 102 West Fiftieth Street, died on Tuesday in the United States Veterans Hospital, the Bronx. His age was 64.

The Allied offensive in the Rhineland, now roaring into its seventh day, is rapidly developing into one of the major victories of the war. Brilliantly conceived and brilliantly executed, it is overrunning the whole German defense system west of the lower Rhine, from Cologne to the original Nijmegen salient.

Allied forces have captured Uedem and advanced to the western edge of the Hochwald, where heavy opposition has been met. Weather limited our air operations in the battle zones yesterday. However, targets at Marienbaum and Sonsbeck were bombed in the morning and again in the afternoon by medium and light bombers. Fighterbombers hit targets at Winnekendonk.
PARIS, Feb. 28--Formal resumption of diplomatic relations between France and Italy, with certain limitations, will be announced tomorrow, high political quarters said tonight.
A large-scale festival of American music will be given in Paris next June, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 28--American tanks broke into the last main natural defense line west of the Rhine today when they rolled over the Erft River on a captured bridge within seven miles of Cologne. They were fighting tonight in hills and woods that a United States First Army staff officer called "the outer defenses of Cologne."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- W. Randolph Burgess, president of the American Bankers Association, told the Senate Banking Committee today that holders of war bonds "will pay through the nose" if the price of gold is increased.

BREDA, the Netherlands, Feb. 26 (Delayed)-- The toll exacted by the sea on the defenseless island of Walcheren, whose dikes were breached by Allied bombers, has been so severe that the entire island is threatened with extinction. Unless engineering equipment to repair the sea walls can be found and delivered in the coming months there will not be time enough to do the job before another winter's storms strike once more.

CHICAGO, March 3 (AP)--The Caterpillar Tractor Company reported today for 1944 a net income of $7,663,913, equal to $4.07 a share, compared with $8,216,354, or $4.37 a share in 1943. PARIS, March 11--Fifty Amercan Wacs are taking advantage of their presence in Paris to attend a sewing course arranged especially for them by the Dressmakers Association. Acceding to the request of restaurant and hotel associations, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday a relaxation of the meatless Tuesdays and Fridays that have been in effect at public eating places here since Jan. 31.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)-- The OPA announced today that standards for determining the ability of wholesalers and retail ers to absorb price increases will in general be the same as those for manufacturers.

PITTSBURGH, March 11--Steel order volume last week, while not as heavy as at the beginning of the year, was, nevertheless, close to the weekly average of the last two months. Trade reports indicate that ti has been running from 35 to 50 per cent ahead of steel shipments.

The National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday that its 360 charter member companies would be awarded special certificates in commemoration of their foundation of the association half a century ago in Cincinnati. Sixty-five are located in New York City, the announcement said.

Seven young singers, three men and four women, were chosen yesterday as finalists in the 1945 "Metropolitan Opera Presents" auditions over the Blue Network. First-nighters will assemble this evening at the Playhouse to examine "It's a Gift," the first of four consecutive premieres scheduled for this week. All hope of the New York Rangers surviving for the playoffs of the National Hockey League was dissolved last night when the Canadiens of Montreal battered the blue-jerseyed sextet into defeat at Madison Square Garden. MIAMI, Fla., March 11 (AP)--Byron Nelson and Harold McSpaden, who finally got the hang of team play and turned into a devasting combination, overwhelmed Sammy Byrd and Denny Shute, 8 and 6, today in the final match of the $7,500 international four-ball golf tournament.

LONDON, March 11--Since the liberation of France a remarkable rise has occurred in French railway sterling bonds on the market here, although not very long ago it was being argued that France would be in no hurry to resume service of these bonds, which went into default in May, 1940. Thousands of war workers, seeking a return to civilian jobs, will share with returning service men the facilities to be afforded by the Veterans' Center to be operated in the former home of the Board of Education at 500 Park Avenue, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 11-Joseph B. Chifley, Treasurer of the Dominion Government, has introduced in the House of Representatives the Government's longawaited banking legislation. WASHINGTON, March 11--Total deposits of the 13,268 insured banks were $125,752,000,000 on Dec. 30, it was reported today by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. This was an increase of $21,636,000,000, or 21 per cent, during the year.
STOCKHOLM, March 11--The American crossing of the Rhine was classed today by a former member of the German General Staff as one of the war's most brilliant military achievements.

Cotton prices in the domestic market dropped last week in the wake of news that American forces had crossed the Rhine. At the close of trading on Saturday on the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts were unchanged to 11 points off, in contrast to an advance of 12 points to a decline of 1 point the week before.

With the naming yesterday of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute all eight berths in the national invitation college basketball tournament have been filled, leaving only the opening-round pairings to be settled before the competition gets under way at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

MANILA, Monday, March 12-- General Doe's infantrymen, veterans of the Palawan invasion on Feb. 28, secured the villages of San Mateo, San Jose, Calarian and San Roque and stabbed eastward along the coast toward the civic center of Zamboanga, only two miles away.

BOSTON, March 11 (AP)--Breaking a six-game losing streak, the Boston Bruins strengthened their National Hockey League play-off chances by overwhelming the Chicago Black Hawks, 7--2, tonight before a 12,000 crowd at the Boston Garden. The setback dropped the visitors out of their fourthplace deadlock with the Bruins.

ROME, March 11--In his first public appearance since his illness, Pope Pius told a delegation from the Christian Workers Association of Italy this morning that he intended to support the cause of the entire world of labor.

GUAM, March 9 (Delayed)-- She was not "scared a bit" in making her first flight as a Navy nurse in a combat area, Ensign Jane Kendeigh said in an interview today. Ensign Kendeigh was one of twelve flight nurses who flew to Iwo March 6 and flew out under Japanese fire with seventeen wounded men.

Corp. Melio Betting, former world light-heavyweight champion, undergoes official examination today at the State Athletic Commission, in advance of his ten-round bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden against Jimmy Bivins, Cleveland heavyweight.

CLEVELAND, March 11 (AP)-- The Indians open spring training tomorrow at Lafayette, Ind., with twenty-four players signed, most of whom will be in camp this week, Vice President Roger Peckinpaugh reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 11--Although synthetic rubber production has reached an all-time peak, the output must be increased 31 per cent in 1945 and 58 per cent in 1946 to meet essential military and civilian transport requirements, the Rubber Reserve Company reported today.

Nine out of ten youngsters working as pin-boys in bowling alleys up-State and .54 per cent of those in New York City are employed in violation of the child labor law, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi disclosed yesterday after a survey by his office staff.

WASHINGTON, March 11--The almost-visible dawn of liberation for Norway was hailed today by Crown Princess Martha and Ambassador Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne at the Norwegian Embassy, celebrating the thirty-third birthday of Girl Scouting with a pledge of 400 suburban Girl Scouts to adopt and outfit the first Girl Scout troop to be organised in liberated Norway.
MOSCOW, March 11--The Rumanian Government proceeded today to clean up opposition elements in the Government service and to institute a sweeping agricultural reform program.

WASHINGTON, March 11-- Calling for the use of $7,000,000,000 a year in public and private funds for the building of new homes after the war, Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York disclosed today plans to introduce legislation to promote housing for city and farm dwellers in low and middle income brackets.

TEHERAN; Iran, March 9 (Delayed)--An American woman employed by the Iranian Government has virtually completed the twelveyear task of making a new compilation and translation of the Koran, together with an additional commentary that some Moslem thinkers believe will have a profound effect on the religious development of Islam.

CHUNGKING, China, March 11 --A series of three-power conferences on future phases of the war against Japan was disclosed today after the departure of Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten, Allied Commander in Chief in Southeast Asia.

LONDON, Monday, March 12-- Soviet troops driving the tip of a wedge between the German defenses of Gdynia and Danzig yesterday reached within eight miles of the former prize port and ten miles of the latter. Berlin, meanwhile, announced that the Russians had hurled 75,000 men into a new offensive at the Moravian Gap gateway to Vienna and Prague.
GUAM, Monday, March 12-- Striking at unprecedentedly low levels, American Superfortress bombers hit Japan early today with a second supercharged attack of incendiary terror.
PARIS, March 11 (AP)--Communique 337 of Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Force:

Two German counter-attacks against the First Army's Remagen bridgehead were broken up by American artillery yesterday while United States tanks and infantry hammered out gains up to a mile, capturing seven towns, including Linz, and fighting into Honnef. At last reports the bridgehead was nine miles long and three deep. The Germans reported another crossing of the Rhine ten miles above Coblenz.

Preaching is primarily the art of teaching with an urgency, the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, the pastor, said yesterday in his sermon in the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, Broadway and 174th Street. He said that preaching was moral and spiritual instruction with a divine plea for obedience.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 11--The Yankee vanguard was billeted her a tonight awaiting the "assembly" that is to sound tomorrow launching the fourth wartime training camp, the third year in which the proving grounds were pitched north of the Potomac, and the first preparatory campaign under the club's new ownership.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 11-- Clarence Uri Carruth, a member of the New York law firm of Washburn, Carruth Scharman, 230 Park Avenue, who had practiced in this State since 1892, died here today at his home, 30 Kingston Road, of heart disease. He was 79 years old.

CHICAGO, March 11--The acute shortage of box cars which has slowed up the movement of cash corn from the country to terminal markets and thence to the East promises to be relieved soon to some extent, although railroad officials deny they are receiving an average of 1,200 empty cars daily from Eastern lines. However, the empty cars are beginning to come back at a more rapid rate than recently.

Francis Carlin, mystical poet, who went into seclusion in 1923 when his verse began to win him a measure of fame, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, the Bronx, after a brief illness. He would have become 63 years old on April 7.

ON THE RHINE, March 11-- British and Canadian patrols on the Rhine today saw Germans frantically digging trenches and foxholes, and laying land mines to strengthen their defenses along the eastern bank of the river, opposite their lost bridgehead. British and Canadian gunners promptly opened up on these works parties.

MOSCOW, March 11--Almost 1,200 officers and men of the United States armed forces who were enabled to escape from German prison camps by the advances of the Red Army have now sailed for American bases from Odessa.

As the Japanese moved to establish complete control over French Indo-China following seizure of the country's key "establishments and facilities" Friday night (Japanese time), the Tokyo radio yesterday declared in an overseas broadcast that the protectorate of Annam had detached itself from the Government-General by a "declaration of independence."

Mayor La Guardia served notice on the gambling fraternity yesterday that he was determined to block their operations at the city's three big league ball parks this summer, even if he has to station Police Commissioner Lewis J. Week-end Courts in Manhattan and Brooklyn took on the aspect of pre-war Traffic Court yesterday as after-curfew drinking patrons paraded in a steady stream before the magistrates. The traffic was all one-way--toward the cage where the clerk-cashier collected the $5 fines.

A four-point program to assure the nation the benefits of free competition in the reconversion of industry from war to peace after V-E Day was offered yesterday by the Economists Committee on Reconversion Problems.

Gustav Frank, a former partner in Frank Brothers Footwear, Inc., a shoe firm having a store at 588 Fifth Avenue, and branch stores in other cities, died on Saturday at his home, 40 Central Park South, after a long illness. His age was 74.

Reporting on operations of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., for the twentysix and fifty-two week periods ended on Jan. 27, Jack I. Straus, president, informed stockholders that sales for both periods reached new highs with record performances being achieved by each subsidiary. His report was for publication today.

ROME, March 11(AP)--The old "practice makes perfect" dictum told the story in the Rome open golf championship today as a pair of Italian professionals who have been able to keep their game sharp deadlocked for the title with 298. Al Zimmerman, Portland (Ore.) pro, who could get in only five practice rounds in more than two years with the Navy, finished behind with 301.

IN THE AHR VALLEY, RHINELAND, March 11--This is a beautiful little valley with steep slopes, intermittent small farms and a quick rushing stream like many valleys in New England. But today it might be called a valley of death.

Financial markets' immediate response to the capture on last Tuesday of Cologne was to rise to the highest average since 1939. On only one day since the present war began--Sept. 13, 1939--did the average rise above 114.15, THE TIMES average for last Tuesday. Although the crossing of the Rhine by the invaders followed, stocks in the last days of the week broke violently, falling more than 4 points.

Koch.

IN the mountains of Haute-Savoie while France still lay prostrate beneath the feet of her conquerors Jean-Nicolas Martin, half American and half French, made a pilgrimage. His journey led him through the valley of despair that was the Europe of the Fascist wars. He fell out of the sky in the night and dug a neat grave in which he buried his parachute.

PARIS, March 13--Maj. Gen. Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, commander of the French First Army, told French and Allied correspondents tonight that 10,000 soldiers of the regular French Army have been killed and 32,000 wounded in seven months of uninterrupted fighting on French soil. They took more than 100,000 prisoners, he added.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, proposed today ceilings on admittance prices to movie houses which, he said, have risen 38 per cent since June, 1941, as well as on stage shows, athletic events and other amusements.

WASHINGTON, March 13-- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate $23,719,153,050 for the Navy for the fiscal year 1946, a figure nearly $5,000,000,000 short of the current budget of $28,500,000,000.

To James Rafferty has gone the unanimous vote of the New York Track Writers Association as the indoor season's outstanding athlete, it was announced yesterday.

The ninth annual exhibition presented by the American Abstract Artists opened yesterday at the Riverside Museum, Riverside Drive at 103d Street. The museum, closed Mondays, is open daily from 1 to 5 P.M., and the show will continue until April 15.

WASHINGTON, March 13--Soft coal operators will reject the demand of the United Mine Workers for a royalty of 10 cents a ton to be used for a social welfare and economic fund, an authoritative source said tonight.

ROME, March 21--Edward J. Flynn, who arrived at Allied Mediterranean Headquarters late yesterday, reached here this afternoon and is a guest of the United States Ambassador, Alexander C. Kirk, pending his audience with Pope Pius, which is understood to have been scheduled but the time has not been announced.

CAPETOWN, March 21 (AP)-- The death of Ralph William Close, envoy to Washington from the, Union of South Africa from 1933 to 1943, was announced today. Mr. Close, who was 77 years old, had been a member of Parliament of the Union of South Africa in 1915-33.
The bloody battle for Iwo Island has been won; the Philippine campaign has opened its last chapter and American forces are probably ready for a new move in the Pacific.

PARIS, March 21--French officials were worried today because they had received no specific promise of Allied aid for French forces in Indo-China in response to a request made through the United States State Department on March 10, immediately after the Japanese struck there.

WITH THE UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, March 21--After the first World War the American Third Army had a relatively easy job in Germany as an army of occupation, but this time it is doing it the hard way.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 21--The Arab countries intend to make a major issue of the question of including Lebanon, Syria and TransJordan in the San Francisco conference or barring there from it.

After announcement by the Alien Property Custodian yesterday that one-half the capital shares of Winthrop Chemical Company of Delaware would be offered at public auction on April 23, James Hill Jr., president of Sterling Drug, Inc., owner of the remaining Winthrop shares, disclosed that Sterling would bid $9,500,000 for the custodian's holdings.
LONDON, March 21--Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden stated tonight in an overture to the San Francisco conference that British policy is opposed to the bullying of small powers by the great ones.

Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican chairman, has finished conferences with the Manhattan Republican Assembly District leaders and has found 80 per cent of them opposed to the renomination of Mayor La Guardia on the Republican ticket, it became known yesterday.

Losses incurred in the two preceding sessions were matched again yesterday by the stock market in a higher volume of selling. Some strong spots appeared among the rails, and the extreme losses in the main section of the list did not carry through to the close.

PARIS, March 21--Henri Frenay, French Minister for Prisoners and Deportees, will meet with United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery and British Ambassador Alfred Duff Cooper tomorrow to propose a joint French-American-British declaration warning the Germans that they will be held responsible for crimes against prisoners of war and foreign civilian laborers.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 20 (AP)--Lieut Gov. Wilbert Snow tried to dissuade a Legislative Committee from authorizing a job for which he had been mentioned as a leading candidate.

OTTAWA, March 21--In all debates by the Canadian Parliament on the Dumbarton Oaks proposals, there has so far been general agreement with the four principal suggestions made by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King for the direction of the delegation at San Francisco. These are:

Because of the flood of actions under the State's new Commercial Rent Law and the absence of precedent for hearing and deciding such cases, the justices of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court have designated Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey to preside over a Special Term, Part 9, to handle all of these actions exclusively.

GUAM, Thursday, March 22--The activities of Admiral Raymond A. Spruance's Fifth Fleet off the coast of the Japanese Empire were cloaked in naval secrecy this morning after a two-day rampage against ships and bases in the Inland Sea of Japan.

CHICAGO, March 21--Confirmation of reports that 1,750,000 bushels of cash rye had been sold for export in the last few days, combined with aggressive buying of futures headed by a professional trader, resulted today in that grain starting a strong rally after an early break of 1 1/8 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel.
LONDON, March 21--Last week's announcement of the Duke of Windsor's resignation from the Governorship of the Bahamas stirred no more than the barest ripple of interest in Britain.

With booming voices that reverberated through Carnegie Hall, where they had assembled for the third annual World Youth Week celebration, 2,000 youths pledged last night to work for lasting peace and to eradicate prejudices by striving for international friendship.

WASHINGTON, March 21--J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, stressing that the tire and rubber programs are "more critical than at any time since Pearl Harbor," today named John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, special director of all WPB activities relating to the production and distribution of rubber products.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.J., March 21 (AP)--Outfielder Leon Culberson joined the Red Sox today as Manager Joe Cronin sent his charges jogging around the muddy field. Then the boys retired to the high school gym for a bit of calisthenics and some throwing.

The third annual Garden Week sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State and the Garden Club of New Jersey opened yesterday in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 21--The Office of Price Administration today named March 25 as the closing date by which Manufacturers of cotton and rayon textiles, under obligation to increase wages according to a ruling by the National War Labor Board, may file applications for price increases.

With the appointment of sixty teachers, the Board of Education wiped out yesterday the elementary grade list that had existed since 1930. New examinations, with higher standards, will be held for grade teachers some time this spring, it was announced.

NEWARK, N.J., March 21-- After six weeks of operation the plan of the War Manpower Commission that aimed at the immediate transfer of 16,000 workers from less essential to high urgency industries in this critical manpower area has achieved slightly more than 3 per cent of its program, an examination of its records today disclosed.

A lively promenade of spring and summer fashions was presented last night at Wanamakers Budget floor. Town clothes were featured with such cool notes as cap sleeves, washable cottons and pastel spun rayons making a bid for the career woman's summer wardrobe.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Each day's deluge of appeals, suggestions and comments with respect to the agenda of the forthcoming conference of the United Nations at San Francisco confirms the belief of officials that a widespread misconception exists of the functions of that conference.

Premier Gen. Kuniaki Koiso and War Minister Field Marshal Gen Sugiyama, predicting that the United States would attempt to invade their homeland, brought pressure to bear on the Imperial Diet yesterday for passage of a new emergency measure designed to turn Japan into an armed camp under virtual military law.

The vital need for immediate political recognition of a Jewish national home and a Jewish State in Palestine by the great powers was stressed by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio and Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver, Zionist leader, at a testimonial dinner for the latter last night at the Hotel Commodore, which was attended by 1,200 persons.

Miscellany from the rod and gun front: The Nassau County Chapter of the Izaak Walton League of America urges sportsmen, conservationists and others to rally to the support of two water pollution control bills which have been presented to Congress.
A little more than two decades have slipped by so quickly that it seems only like yesterday since "The Firebrand" was the toast of Broadway.

CALCUTTA, India, March 21 (AP)--Allied ground troops increased their pressure on 30,000 Japanese squeezed in the seventyfive-mile-deep pocket between Mandalay and Meiktila today as fighter planes slashed at the enemy's major escape route from central Burma to Thailand.

PARIS, March 21--The great American victory in the Palatinate is almost complete, The irresistible armored divisions of the American Third Army slashed seven to twelve miles through the disorganized Germans today, entering Ludwigshafen on the Rhine and smashing southward beyond Neustadt to narrow the German escape route to the east to less than twenty miles.

WASHINGTON, March 21--The "masterpiece of human relationship achieved by the United States" in the Philippines should be emphasized at the United Nations Conference in San Francisco, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, the Resident Commissioner for the Islands, told a news conference today.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., March 21 (AP)--Capt. John Tiebor, a pioneer in the training of sea lions for show business, who exhibited his animal troupes throughout the United States and Europe, died here today in his home. His age was 86.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Army replacement depots in Italy not only are keeping up with the needs of the combat forces there but also have shipped out a considerable number of ground-force replacements to the European fighting zone, according to an official report just received at the War Department.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 21 --For criticizing Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's aerial policy and "other defeatist activities," two air marshals of the Luftwaffe have been arrested and now face court-martial, according to information to the Swiss press from Berlin.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 21 (AP) --An increase in the advertising tax on oranges from one to two cents a box has been approved formally by four citrus groups representing between 80 and 90 per cent of the Florida industry.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Refunds to the United States Treasury of more than $5,800,000,000 and further savings described as "vast but impossible to estimate" have resulted from Government practices of renegotiating war contracts during the past three years, Col. Maurice Hirsch, chairman of the War Contracts Price Adjustment Board, announced today.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 21-- There is a vast baseball factory about to go into operation here to grind out much-needed talent and not the least remarkable feature of the undertaking is the fact that it will be run by the Giants.

A guaranteed annual wage has long been an aspiration of workers in seasonal occupations or in industries subject to extreme oscillations of prosperity and depression. Every measure ought to be adopted that would help to solve or diminish this problem.

Criticizing advocates of a change in the voting procedure at the coming world security conference in San Francisco, the Moscow radio declared in a broadcast reported yesterday by the Federal Communications ...

Tami Mauriello and Lee Oma yesterday finished hard training in preparation for their third meeting tomorrow night at Madison square Garden, a bout that already has an advance sale of $85,000, according to officials.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, March 21--Appointment of a public representative to each of WMC's Management-Labor Committees was recommended today by the Women's Advisory Committee to the War Manpower Commission.

CHICAGO, March 21--Stockholders of the National Tea Company today elected an unopposed nine-man compromise board of directors, pledged to end long-standing differences between the management and certain stockholders over the operation of the large Midwest food chain.

ROME, March 21--Rumors of an imminent break between Spain and Japan received fresh impetus here today when it was learned that the Vatican was protesting strongly to Tokyo's representative, Ken Harada, concerning the execution of Franciscan monks in Manila.

RICHMOND, Va., March 21 (AP) --The resignations of J. Cloyd Kent and Overton D. Dennis as trustees of the Central States Electric Corporation were accepted today by Judge Robert N. Pollard in orders filed in the Federal district court. Mr. Kent was made a trustee in February, 1942, and Mr. Dennis in August, 1942.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 --Hal B. Wallis, Paramount producer, has announced plans to make a screen musical biography of Tchaikovsky. The screen play will be written by Ayn Rand, author of "The Fountainhead," who worked on the script of Wallis' recent production, "The Love Letters."

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP)--Montgomery Ward Co. reported today net profit of $21,285,839, equal to $3.81 a common share, for the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, compared with $20,677,098, or $3.69 a share, for the previous year.

Faced by the threat that Army military policemen and Navy shore patrols would visit their establishments at midnight and compel all personnel of the armed forces to leave, most of the leading night clubs and hotels of the city and many other bars and places of entertainment voluntarily reverted last night to the midnight curfew hour.

ALBANY, March 21--Thirtysix specific proposals for improving fiscal and employment practice within the Legislature were submitted today to the Legislature by the joint legislative committee it named a year ago to investigate "legislative methods, practices, procedures and expenditures."
With the arrest of two men and a woman yesterday, the police revealed that they had broken up a gang of narcotics peddlers that held up gasoline service stations and stole clothing as sidelines.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- W. Randolph Burgess, president of the American Bankers Association, warned the House Banking and Currency Committee today of "very grave dangers" in the Bretton Woods proposals, but pointed to the recommendations made on Monday by the Committee for Economic Development as offering a possible compromise.
SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, March 21--This city, once the most important industrial and coal mining center of the Saar Valley, is little more than a rubble heap today.

Commissioner of Health Ernest L. Stebbins announced yesterday that thirty-two residents of Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx had become victims of trichinosis as a result of eating mettwurst and similar products made from incompletely processed pork.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 21-- Big Red--a prize homing pigeon-- came home today. It might have been just plain boredom with Army life or it might have been spring.
LONDON, March 21--Field Marshal Viscount Wavell, Viceroy and Governor General of India, is on his way to London to discuss India's role in the Far Eastern war and to review the political situation.
Operators disposed of several apartment properties in the upper West Side, Morningside and Washington Heights sections in deals reported yesterday.
PARIS, March 21--The parade of spring fashions drew to a close today when Hermes, famous for leather goods and sports clothes, showed a collection adapted to the demands of the day.

The Coordinating Committee of American-Polish Associations in the East made public yesterday an appeal addressed to the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate requesting an immediaite hearing on "the intolerable conditions in Poland."

ALBANY, March 21--Thirty-six specific proposals for improvement of the fiscal and employment practices within the Legislature were submitted today to New York's Senators and Assemblymen by the Joint Legislative Committee that was named by the two houses a year ago to investigate "legislative methods, practices, procedures and expenditures."

SOMEWHERE IN THE NETHERLANDS, March 21--Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands has returned to her native soil for a brief but deeply moving visit among her own people after four years and ten months of exile in England.

WASHINGTON, March 21--The marriage of Miss Hilda Munson, daughter of Col. Frederic Granville Munson, USA, and Mrs. Munson, of this city, to Ensign Robert James Walton 3d, USNR, took place at noon today in St. Alban's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Charles T. Warner.

The Regional War Labor Board denied yesterday the request of Radio Station WOV for an order reducing the quota of musicians to be hired according to its contract with Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, and ordered continuation of the present practice, it was announced by Thomas L. Norton, chairman of the board. Industry members dissented.
A. Kaufman of Arnold Constable Co., has been elected chairman of the Metropolitan Traffic and Receiving Unit, succeeding Hugh Bright of Saks-Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Consolidation of the country's overseas communications services was urged today by Paul A. Porter, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who took issue, however, with the type of merger advocated by the Navy Department, at the opening of hearings before the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee on International Communications.
CRIES of pain are seldom pleasant to overhear, but few kinds of human expression prove more instructive. Anyone who reads "The Power House," a novel by Alex Comfort, must be prepared for pain.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 21 (AP)--The Very Rev. Samuel R. Colladay of West Hartford, dean emeritus of Christ Church Cathedral in Hartford, died last night in Hartford Hospital.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP)--Tomorrow's railway ticket may be a child's passport to a rolling wonderland as a result of the "junior club car" designed by the PullmanStandard Car Manufacturing Company and described by Ellis W. Test, assistant to the president, in charge of engineering and research.

LONDON, March 21--The Polish National Council, wartime parliamentary body established when the Polish Government was set up in London, was dissolved by a decree of President Wladislaw Raczkiewicz tonight.

LONDON, March 21--Public concern over the question of food supplies brought the topic to the fore again today in the House of Commons, where Prime Minister Churchill informed Members that reserve stocks at present totaled less than six million tons.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek supports sentiments outlined in peace proposals previously advanced by the Catholic War Veterans, Inc., and looks toward "a peace founded on justice, equality and freedom for all," it was reported yesterday.

Shields Co. and associates received yesterday the award of $2,530,000 of refunding bonds of Lincoln Park, Mich., on a bid of 100.0101 for a combination of interest rates and maturities, representing a net interest cost of 2.426 per cent.

Harvey isn't the only popular rabbit this season, a check of candy and novelty shops disclosed yesterday. At Dennison's it was reported that the "Easter bunny has definitely supplanted the Easter chick and duck in popularity," which other sources cor roborated.

Ford Frick, president of the National League, last night hailed the decision of the War Manpower Commission by which baseball players who held war plant jobs during the off-season are permitted to return to the diamond without obtaining certificates of availability or referral cards.
Cotton for future delivery developed irregularity yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and closed 2 points higher to 12 points lower than on Tuesday.
"99 Park," headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, Inc., offers a partial list of free amusements available today through the generosity of the entertainment world.
One fish that appears on the market with comparative regularity is flounder, a species that includes such varieties as lemon sole, gray sole, yellowtails and blackback.

LONDON, Thursday, March 22 --The United States Eighth Air Force burned and bombed ten airfields in northwestern Germany yesterday in a punishing blow against swift jet planes that the Germans have thrown into battle in increasing numbers recently to halt the day-and-night bombing of the Reich.

MOSCOW, March 21 (AP)--The magazine War and the Working Class exhorted American newspapers today to "give true and complete information about our country," and accused a section of the American press of "falsifying" reports about Russia during the last quarter century.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 21-- Frank Wright Noxon, author, journalist and economist, died here yesterday at the age of 72.
LOU NOVIKOFF departed so quietly from the big league scene that the Mad Russian probably is forgotten already. But that's no way to treat our Looie.

CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo., March 21 (AP)--The Browns reaped two runs off three singles and a double, while Pitchers Sig Jakucki and Rookie Al Lamacchia shut out Toledo of the American Association on one hit to win their first exhibition game today, 2 to 0.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Conferees on the stalemated House and Senate bills for manpower mobilization studied in their offices today the Austin compromise proposal and later agreed generally that it was a stronger measure than either of the bills it seeks to tie together.

Charges that insurance companies are discouraging rehabilitation and employment of disabled veterans by charging higher rates to cover factories employing handicapped workers were labeled a "grave misconception" yesterday by J. Dewey Dorsett, general manager of the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives, at the local insurance conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 21--A War Manpower Commission ruling making it possible for ball players to leave essential industries without being referred to draft boards as job jumpers reached the Yankees like a ray of sunshine on this dismal day.

Mrs. Phyllis Altglass of Glen Cove, L.I., found she was really "taken to the cleaners" when, after waiting six months for the return of her $3,500 Persian rug from the Carolyn Carpet Cleaning Company, 435 East 162d Street, the Bronx, she learned last Saturday from an anonymous telephone caller that the rug had been sold for $725.

Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal declared yesterday that as many as 12,000 of the 15,300 fighting men wounded on Iwo Island might be completely restored to health, with reports indicating that between 6,000 and 7,000 had returned to their divisions before the fall of Iwo.

In a record-breaking, historymaking basketball game at Madison Square Garden last night, George Mikan of De Paul University just about rewrote the book as he Faced his mates to an incredible 97-53 victory over Rhode Island State in the semi-final round of the eighth annual national invitation tournament.

BOSTON, March 21 (AP)--Willie Hoppe set a new world record this afternoon and then passed Champion Welker Cochran tonight in the final Boston block of their 5,400-point transcontinental threecushion billiard match for the world title at the City Club.

WASHINGTON, March 21--The manufacture of new planes, rather than the conversion of military aircraft, to provide for the imperative needs of the country's air transport system, was urged by Henry Nelson, director of the aircraft division of the War Production Board at a press conference today.
The City Planning Commission took yesterday the first concrete step toward revision of the city's master plan to make possible after the war the proposed $50,000,000 Brooklyn Civic Center.

Hosiery cannot be brought under M-388 without a basic change in that order which would make it possible to extend AA-4 priorities back to yarn producers, it was asserted yesterday by hosiery industry spokesmen.

The 1944 annual report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., forwarded to shareholders yesterday, shows a consolidated net income for the year of $30,374,720, after all expenses and taxes.

The mighty carrier Midway, just christened at Newport News, can be accepted as the shape of things to come. Nothing like her exists in any other navy of the world. But in the years ahead the Seven Seas will be patrolled by whole fleets of these giant ships.
The battle of the Westwall is coming to a close with one of the greatest Allied victories in this war and the greatest American victory in history.

The Klein Jackson Construction Company bought the fourstory business building at 26 East Twenty-third Street from the Guaranty Trust Company for cash over a mortgage of $61,500. Joseph Milner was the broker in the sale of the parcel, which is assessed at $72,000.

Arthur Besse was re-elected president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers at the annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Commodore. The meeting was conducted largely through proxies and was combined with a meeting of the new board of directors.
ROME, March 21 (AP)--Fighting in western Liguria between 500 Germans and Italian patriots was reported today in a Fifteenth Army Group communique.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, in the Rhineland, March 21--Adolf Hitler has lived to see the day when the most farmiliar "figure" in Germany is neither himself nor any of his stooges but one of their enemies.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- The Senate continued today discussion of the Presidential nomination of Aubrey Williams to be Rural Electrification Administrator. The issue was expected to come to a vote tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Among 6,361 Army and 262 Navy casualties announced today by the War and Navy Departments, all based upon prior notification to next of kin, were the following (the name following the casualty is that of the next of kin):

After the Second Battle of the Philippines last October Admiral King said that practically every ship the Japanese had left after three years of war was engaged there.

The problem of distributing food to those who need it is too vital to the solution of nearly every other problem to be clouded by acrimonious arguments on what country gives most, or gives up most, to help make the limited supply go round.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21--Half a dozen British Mosquitos bombed Gestapo headquarters in the United States-owned five story Shell House office building right in the center of Copenhagen at noon today.

MOSCOW, March 21--The Soviet Union's denunciation yesterday of the Russo-Turkish treaty of friendship of 1925 did not come as a great surprise to diplomatic circles. Since Turkey went to war last month and thus became an ally of Soviet Russia the original treaty conditions have certainly become altered.

The teacher who formerly was on the receiving end is giving apples to her pupils these days to help move a record crop out of storage before too much of the fruit rots.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 21--The Dodgers today came up with a southpaw pitcher to add to their staff. He is the pint-sized Victor Lombardi, who has been in camp since opening day but at whom Branch Rickey got his first real look this morning.
MANILA, Thursday, March 22 --Maj. Gen. Rapp Brush's Fortieth Division has captured Iloilo, capital of Panay, entering the streets at 1:20 P.M. Tuesday, the communique announced today.

Net sales, billings and other income of the Packard Motor Car Company in 1944 reached a new high of $455,692,753, increasing $114,431,103, or 33.5 per cent over the $341,261,650 volume the year before, George T. WASHINGTON, March 21-- Baseball got another break today in a decision by the War Manpower Commission that players may return to the game from off-season employment, such as war plant jobs.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- John Foster Duller of New York, chief foreign policy adviser to Governor Thomas E. Dewey in the 1944 Presidential campaign, rejected today a suggestion that he attend the conference of the United Nations on world security at San Francisco late next month as an attache to the official American delegation.

LONDON, Thursday, March 22 --Russian troops forged a powerful twenty-five-mile siege arc south and west of Danzig yesterday, pushed a new spearhead to within six miles southwest of the former free city and drove within two miles of cutting the DanzigGdynia coastal road, Moscow announced last night.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 26 (AP)--Byron Nelson won the Charlotte open golf tournament today, defeating Sam Snead by four strokes in a second 18-hole playoff--a grim match played before an almost silent gallery of some 1,800 persons.

C. Sherman Hoyt, famed American skipper who figured prominently in the yacht races between this country and England before the advent of the hostile underwater craft, chose last night to venture into the tricky waters of the theatrical straits as producer of "Eternal Cage" at the BarbizonPlaza Theatre.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)-- Chairman Mead of the Senate War Investigating Committee said today that the War Manpower Commission had agreed to consider a modification of its critical job-area classification system.

Dr. William Jephtha Calvert, formerly of Englewood, N.J., who spent his early career as an Army surgeon, teacher of medicine and as a contributor to medical publications, died yesterday in Daytona Beach, Fla., after a long illness. His age was 73. His former residence in Englewood was at 160 Lincoln Street.

The executive committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will meet here today to analyze M-580, the new Office of Price Administration order which freezes retail mark-ups as of last Monday.

ALBANY, March 21--The DiCostanzo bill extending commercial rent control in New York City to retail store and office space was passed unanimously today in the Senate with Democratic members expressing regret that amendments they offered rolling the basic freeze date back to 1943 had been rejected by the Republican majority.

The likelihood that legislation vitally affecting the lives of children in this State may be passed at Albany without open hearings drew vigorous protest in this city yesterday from individuals concerned with children's welfare.
LONDON, March 21--The best feature of a generally quiet stock market today was the general rise in gilt-edge stocks following the announcement of the terms of the bid Australian conversion loan.

TORONTO, March 22 (Canadian Press)--Premier George A. Drew's Progressive Conservative Government was defeated by a 51-36 vote tonight on a Cooperative Commonwealth Federation amendment to the address in reply to the speech from the throne.

A broad inquiry into food production and distribution has been authorized by the Senate and proposed in the House. These inquiries appear to have been prompted by the fears of an impending food shortage.

The first steps in the creation of a national program among employers, workers and health agencies to cut the rate of absenteeism by reducing preventable accidents and illnesses were reported yesterday by the Fort Greene Industrial Health Committee, organized a year ago in Brooklyn's most concentrated factory district.
MADRID, March 22--Substantially increased commerce between Spain and the United States was predicted today by Capt. Ralph H. Ackerman, American Embassy ...

LONDON, March 22--Repeated demands that coordinated control for Britain's vast rehousing program be vested in a single individual characterized debate on this ticklish and important legislation in the House of Commons today.

LONDON, March 22--Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced today the appointment of a nine-member British delegation to the San Francisco World Security Conference that, like the United States delegation, gives strong representation to both principal political parties and at the same time notable recognition to Labor and the women's vote.
You won't have to worry about ice if you plan to fish the local reservoirs and lakes when the trout season opens.

A syndicate of investors headed by Irving Brodsky, attorney, bought the fourteen-story apartment house for forty-five families at 166-74 West Eighty-sixth Street from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $400,000 for fifteen years.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 22--The Arab League conference here adopted the final draft of its constitution with its signature here tonight by six of the member States.

Encouraged by an absence of any pressure at the opening, buyers returned yesterday to the stock market but in limited force.

MEXICO CITY, March 24--The ousting of Generalissimo Francisco Franco in Spain will be demanded by international organized labor at the conference for the creation of a world security organization in San Francisco next month, Mexican and Spanish labor leaders said at a meeting held to discuss Spain's internal conditions and relations after the war.
Edwin Justus Mayer's famous "Firebrand" came back to town last evening. It did so in the guise of Max Gordon's latest musical, and this time it is called "The Firebrand of Florence." Second ...

The Board of Estimate yesterday voted to fix a charge of $1 a room for every room in excess of two, for use of water in buildings or apartments available for occupancy by boarders, roomers or lodgers.

DETROIT, March 22 (AP)--Boston seized a commanding 2-0 lead in games over Detroit in their firstround Stanley Cup hockey playoff series by outskating and outshooting the Red Wings, 4 to 2, before 12,136 fans at Olympia tonight.

Stockholders of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company, manufacturer of office equipment, approved yesterday a change in the company name to Underwood Corporation along with other proposals submitted at the annual meeting of stockholders.

It must have been a melancholy satisfaction to former Justice John Hessin Clarke in his declining years to see the American people forced by a second world war, more catastrophic than the first, to turn to a new league of nations as the best hope of future peace.

LONDON, March 22--On the eve of their departure for the United States after spending a month in the British Isles surveying industrial conditions, four American women trade unionists, at a press conference this morning, chorused their dismay at the extent of child labor they had encountered in their travels.

CHICAGO, March 22--Total deposits of banks in this area decreased in the first quarter of this year from the high record of Dec. 30, although savings deposits rose to more than $1,000,000,000, statements of condition as of March 20 showed today.

GUAM, Friday, March 23--Life in Japan under American bombing attacks has become a nightmare of regimentation, shortages, black markets, desolation and general disruption, an analysis of enemy home-front radio broadcasts reveals.

WASHINGTON, March 22--Stars are being pinned on the shoulders of already high-ranking officers, particularly those of the Army, in such profusion that the Senate Military Affairs Committee today questioned General Marshall about it.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22-- A special three-judge expediting United States District Court today gave Pullman, Inc., one year in which to contract for the sale of either the capital stock or the assets of its $80,000,000 servicing business.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- Foreign Commissar V.M. Molotoff of Russia; Sir Archibald Clark Kerr, the British Ambassador to Russia, and W. All principal domestic securities and commodity exchanges will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. With the exception of the New York wool and cotton markets and the New Orleans cotton market, trading will resume on Saturday. Livestock and dairy markets will be open as usual today.

Loans and investments of the major New York banks showed a further decrease for the week ended last Wednesday, according to the combined statement of the sixteen reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System issued yesterday. The General Motors Corporation, leading producer of war materials in the United States, last year again broke all war and peacetime records with sales and other revenue of $4,276,184,761, comparing with $3,820,607,289 in 1943, according to the annual report signed by Alfred P. ROCHESTER, March 31 (AP)-- Haloid Company workers made a claim of being first in the country to top their quota in the Seventh War Loan, which opens April 9. The firm was one of the first ten in the country to make its Sixth War Loan goal.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (AP) --The Maritime Commission announced today that thirty-six ships of various designs were delivered by East Coast shipyards this month. They included nine Victory ships, eight Liberties, seven tankers, five standard cargo and four military type ships.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 31 (AP) --Mrs. Emily Spreckels, fourth wife of Adolph B. Spreckels, the sugar heir who was recently inducted into the Army, obtained a divorce from him here today by default decree. They were married at Reno on Aug. 10, 1939. She was the widow of Baron Maximilian von Romberg, who was killed in a plane crash at Fair Haven, Conn., in June, 1938.

The trucks, the announcement said, will be used to distribute relief materials from this country and "will play an important role in feeding the Italian people because there is no other means of transportation."

WASHINGTON, March 31-- There occurred here in the past week an example of the interplay of politics in the handling of veterans' affairs which might be comic if it were not so serious in its outlook for the 15,000,000 potential veterans of this war.

LONDON, March 31 (AP)--John S. Dodd, president of the Association of British Chambers of Commerce, said today that favorable action by Congress on President Roosevelt's recent request for powers to slash tariffs would prove a boon to Great Britain.

Morris J. Solomon, secretary of the Davis Yarn Company, 370 Hart Street, Brooklyn, has been named chairman of the 1945 Brooklyn drive of the Joint Defense Appeal of the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, it was announced yesterday by Alan M. Stroock, New York campaign chairman. Mr. Solomon was named as Brooklyn's leading citizen for 1944 by the Men's League of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP)-- The Navy told today how a group of 452 Marshall Island natives threatened with slaughter by their Japanese captors, was snatched to safety recently in a dramatic rescue operation.

LONDON, March 31 (Canadian Press)--Mighty Aston Villa, winner of the English League North football cup last season, was eliminated today as the first round was completed before tremendous holiday crowds.

The class of 1928 of the Packer Colegiate Institute will hold a card party at the institute on Saturday afternoon for the benefit of the Packer Centennial Fund. The proceeds will be included in a class gift to be presented at the centennial dinner at hte Waldorf-Astoria on May 9.

GUAM, Sunday, April 1--In a series of synchronized blows the Fifth Fleet hit Japanese bases and fortified points in a smashing, widespread offensive as battleships and light craft moved in Friday and bombarded Okinawa, main island of the Ryukyus, with heavy, devastating fire at close range. Carrier planes joined in the attack, striking many targets.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 31-- Mr. and Mrs. James J. Sullivan of Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Patricia, to J. Wakeman Jennings Jr. of the Marine Corps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jennings of this place.

AN outdoor carnation not seen often enough in borders and cut-flower gardens is Cha baud's everblooming giant hybrid. It is very fragrant, more so than many modern greenhouse varieties. An excellent flower for cutting and decorative work, it is just as effective in the garden. This carnation is treated as an annual, since it blooms five months after sowing.

An important investment deal consisting of forty-five lots in Sunnyside on the outskirts of Long Island City is announced by King King, Jackson Heights brokers, for improvement following the war with three-story garden type apartment houses.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP)--Stockholders of the Signode Steel Strapping Company will vote April 10 on a proposal to issue a 100 per cent stock dividend on the common, directors announced today. Since 150,410.05 shares now are outstanding, the dividend, if ratified, would result in there being 300,820.1 outstanding.
