WASHINGTON, March 31-- James M. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, will ask Congress on Monday to enact legislation making decisions of the War Labor Board enforceable in the Federal courts, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- Staff Sgt. George J. Hall, infantryman, who knocked out two German machine-gun nests on the Anzio beachhead, May 23, 1944, killing seven Germans and capturing nine, has been cited for award of the Congressional Medal of Honor, the War Department announced today.

PARIS, Sunday, April 1--Maurice Donnay, a member of the French Academy, died in Paris last night of heart disease. His age was 86. As a writer and playwright he was essentially a survivor of the "Naughty Nineties" of the last century.

CHICAGO, March 31--The Government's appeal from Federal District Judge Philip L. Sullivan's decision of Jan. 27 that President Roosevelt's order to seize Montgomery Ward Co. properties was illegal was filed today in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

The Richfield Oil Corporation, in its annual report for 1944 to be mailed today to stockholders, disclosed a net income of $3,935,396 after all charges, including taxes and provision for contingencies, equal to 98 cents each on 4,010,000 shares of common stock.

ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., March 31--One man was arrested as agents of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury Department conducted a raid on a large still which was in operation on a farm in Manalapan Township, between here and Freehold, this afternoon. The nine-room residence on a plot of one acre on Greenfield Hill Fairfield, Conn., has been sold by William R. Webster Jr., to Mrs. Charlotte B. Ogle, tenant of the house for two years. It has a large frontage on Greenfield Road and overlooks Long Island Sound. The deal was closed by the Fairfield Land Title Company through Miss Ysabel A. Muecke.

The large rise in farm land values during the war period has caused much concern in official quarters. According to OPA Administrator Bowles, the rise during the past two years has been at an annual rate of about 14 per cent. This increase may be attributable to several factors.

BALTIMORE, March 31 (AP)-- The last of the Marauders was off the Glenn L. Martin Company's assembly line today and was turned over to the United States Air Forces. The Marauder B-26 medium bomber, once the target of Senate Committee criticism because of claimed take-off and landing difficulties, has figured as a vital air combat weapon. Production was stopped, the company said, because the Army now needed longer-range bombers.
LONDON, March 31 (AP)--The German Ambassador to Japan conferred yesterday with the Japanese Foreign Minister on "important matters," the Tokyo radio said today without giving and details.

With the approval by the Legislature, as one of its closing acts, of the bill to establish a temporary commission to map plans for the establishment of post-high-school technical institutes, New York State has embarked upon an extremely valuable post-war educational program.

BRUSSELS, March 31--Belgium is awaiting with some anxiety the next phase in her liberation, namely, the withdrawal of the Allied liberating armies. A current tendency to blame the Allies for the troubles of the country will be sharpened, it is felt, as conditions probably will become worse before solid improvement can be realized.

WASHINGTON, March 31-- Racing people tonight formally received from War Mobilization Director James F. Byrnes the word they have been awaiting for weeks --that the ban on their sport will be lifted on V-E day.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 31--Lee W. Berry, former general superintendent of several railroads and retired general agent of the New York Long Branch (N.J.) Railroad, died at his home here yesterday. OTTAWA, March 31--The tenday debate in the Canadian Parliament on the San Francisco program that ended Wednesday with an almost unanimous vote of approval of the purposes and principles of the Dumbarton Oaks proposals as "a satisfactory general basis for discussion" did a great deal to clear away in the minds of those who listened illusions and misconceptions and to underline the real difficulties that may be expected when Germany and Japan are defeated.

HEADQUARTERS OF ALLIED LAND FORCES, Southeast Asia, March 31--Japanese opposition is rapidly being crushed in the Mandalay-Meiktila pocket and enemy troops, still fighting in an organized manner, seem to be slipping out of the pocket as quickly as they can get away.

LONDON. IRWIN SHAW'S play, "The As sassin" was produced here last week at the Savoy Theatre and, in my judgment, it is likely to have a good run. ROME, March 31 (U.P.)--Allied planes have severed every enemy rail line facing the British Eighth Army in central and northeastern Italy, it was announced today, as Allied ground armies maintained their toehold on the southern rim of the Po Valley.
Gregory Luban, 35 years old, was found hanged from a steampipe in the bathroom of his fourroom suite at the Hotel Sherman Square, Seventy-first Street and Broadway, at 7 o'clock last night.

ATLANTA, March 31--Demands for Easter goods continued unusually strong in the Sixth Federal Reserve District last week. Sale of thirty reporting department stores were 26 per cent greater for the week and 7 per cent improved for the four weeks ended last Saturday compared with the corresponding periods of last year. All leading centers reported gains for both periods.

ONIONS are being planted in many gardens this week end. There is more to having a good crop, however, than just planting and waiting and harvesting. They may be started from seeds, from plants or from sets. Many varieties are listed, with considerable difference among them. And the place to grow them must be carefully prepared.

OPERATING on the theory that practically everyone has an ambition to emulate the fabled detectives of fact and fiction, WOR-Mutual will unveil a murder mystery series featuring nation-wide audience participation. ALBANY, March 31--Governor Dewey signed today the Bennett bill for increased State aid for dependent children. He said it was one of the important measures enacted during the Legislative session.

Thomas S. McLane, president of Roosevelt Hospital, announced yesterday that the Ninth Evacuation Hospital Unit, recruited from its staff, has won the Distinguished Unit Award for meritorious service in the French campaign. Formed in 1942, the unit treated more than half of all the wounded who were hospitalized in the Tunisian campaign.

LEAD, S.D., April 1 (AP)--An Easter storm tonight had covered the Northern Blackhills area of South Dakota with eight inches of heavy, wet snow and was continuing with temperatures generally in the 20's.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 1-- Present transportation difficulties due to the lack of tires and the closing of river transport by the drought have increased the demand for air transport in which Colombia long has been the leader in Latin America. Sutherland Jr., USNR, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sutherland, also of Yonkers. The bride-elect, daughter also of John Stewart of Arbroath, Scotland, attended Teachers College in Cortland, N.Y. ROSAMOND LEHMANN's first novel in eight years, "The Ballad and the Source," is an original, peculiar and moderately baffling study of the timeless mystery of human personality. It is also a highly romantic, almost Gothic, melodrama told in an elaborate and artificial manner, with enormous subtlety and skill, but without much illusion of reality.

The square block of twelve factory buildings in Paterson, N.J., formerly owned by the estate of Franz C. Reinhardt, who built them, has been acquired by Giant Mills, Inc., represented by J.L. Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange last week registered moderate gains. At the close of trading on Thursday active future contracts showed net gains for the period of 1 to 16 points. There was no trading on Good Friday or on Saturday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 1 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd W. Weed of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Priscilla E., to Pvt. Henry W. Krager, AUS, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Krager of Binghamton, N.Y.

ROME, April 1 (AP)--The stalemate in the ground fighting in Italy continued today. Scattered patrol clashes and minor artillery fire were reported by the Allied high command. There were no changes in forward positions.

OTTAWA, April 1 (AP)--The Canadian Army suffered 2,661 casualties in February, defense headquarters announced tonight. This week-end housewives will find egg supplies just about adequate but how long they will continue to be so is a question, according to the trade.

THE world has never had enough to eat. Today in Europe and Asia so many millions of persons are starving or so close to it that it seems likely that our age will long be one of famine. In America, supposedly so well fed and prosperous, some 40,000,000 persons are estimated to be suffering from faulty diet.

The stock market surrendered yesterday some of its hard-won recoveries in continued listless trading. Losses ranged from major fractions to around 2 points as selling which developed soon after mid-day revealed an extremely thin market.

The Mayflower, or trailing arbutus, is a shy and sensitive giver of beauty. All winter long the plants have hidden under protecting leaves of maples, oaks and birches. Now the April sun sends its warming rays slanting onto rocky hillsides, into glens and ravines. The evergreen alternating leaves are pushing up to meet the new season.
Cutbacks in procurement of cotton duck by the Army are due within thirty days on the basis of present developments of the war in Europe, Worth Street commis-- sion men predicted yesterday.

AT SEA, March 15 (Delayed)-- The wounded from Iwo Island and from other Pacific islands were high-spirited as the huge Navy transport, divided into immaculate wards, bore them swiftly Statesward on smooth waters.

LONDON, April 5--Another great fleet of American planes-- more than 1,200 bombers escorted by 600 fighters--attacked a variety of vital targets in southern Germany today and by nightfall the shrinking Reich had shuddered to a series of blows by more than 5,000 Allied planes operating from Britain alone within the last twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Representatives of industry, labor and governmental agencies principally concerned with American industrial development agreed generally today at a conference sponsored by the American Legion that full employment for veterans depended very largely in the future on a high level employment for thecountry as a whole.

CHICAGO, April 5--Trading in rye was somewhat listless today on the Board of Trade, lacking yesterday's aggressive short covering, and professional traders who were on the buying side recently were disposed to accept some of the profits made on the advance of 13 cents a bushel from Saturday's close.

WASHINGTON, April 5--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has informed President Roosevelt that it is becoming increasingly probable that "there will never be a clearcut military surrender" of the German forces on the Western Front.

Loans by the New York City banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System continued to decline in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the combined statement of the sixteen reporting member banks, as released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
CALCUTTA, India, April 5-- United States Army Services of Supply troops here unloaded in March the biggest tonnage of American supplies so far discharged during any one month at this port.

WASHINGTON, April 5--The War Labor Board notified John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, tonight that unless strikes at 200 mines were "terminated promptly," the Government would seize the mines.

PARIS, April 5--An undisclosed number of German prisoners of war suffocated in the course of a rail journey from the American front to prisoner of war camps on March 15 and 16, according to an announcement made by this headquarters today.

Superintendent of Schools John E. Wade announced yesterday that the 825 public schools of New York City will serve next week as collection depots for contributions to the United National Clothing Collection for the relief of needy persons in war-torn countries.
WASHINGTON, April 5--Russia's denunciation of the neutrality pact with Japan today was hailed enthusiastically here as a highly important development in the war of the Pacific.

A shell-torn foxhole on the black, sandy stretches of Iwo is a tiny spot for New Yorkers to meet, but two policemen who pounded adjacent beats in Harlem met there for the first time as their division hit the beach on Feb. 19, according to a letter received yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

Economy and efficiency of superoctane gasoline for post-war domestic airline operations was questioned yesterday at the aeronautical meeting of the metropolitan section of the Society of Automotive Engineers at the Hotel New Yorker.

"Dinner for 3" is being taken off tomorrow night in Boston for overhauling. Written and staged by Tim Whelan, Hollywood director, the comedy arrived in the Hub last Monday and was scheduled to remain there a second week before coming to Broadway.

Army Day will be celebrated today at noon with a public meeting on the steps of the Sub-Treasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets, and tomorrow afternoon with a parade down Fifth Avenue from Ninetieth to Sixty-fourth Street.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 5--Carrying a mid-season playing poundage of 175 and a first baseman's glove, Augie Galan blew into camp today along with a somewhat wintry wind, worked out with the squad for two hours and pronounced himself ready for anything that may happen.

Thomas, a Los Angeles business man, just returned from a 30,000-mile tour of the Pacific on a morale and recreational survey for the Secretary of the Navy, announced today he would recommend that the Navy establish and print a newspaper on Guam for distribution to its men in that area.

The Republic of Liberia has transmitted to the Liberian Consul General here a check in the amount of $350,000 to be applied to the purchase for redemption of that amount of its 7 per cent gold bonds. By this payment the Republic will have reduced its foreign outstanding indebtedness to less than $800,000. The National City Bank acts as fiscal agents for the Liberian Government.

WASHINGTON, April 6--The War Food Administration will recommend to the Office of Price Administration that it increase the ration point allowance for seaboard fishermen to give them a diet of 5,000 calories a day.
LONDON, April 6--United States First Army troops today captured a trainload of V-2 stratosphere rockets, offering Allied scientists their first opportunity to study Adolf Hitler's secret weapon.

OKINAWA, April 6--Ship radios broadcast the news of the Russian denunciation of the Japanese neutrality pact and the subsequent resignation of Koiso Cabinet to portable radio sets in the front lines today, inaugurating a wave of excitement over the entire Okinawa beachhead.

The first class of volunteers trained as Field Army Nursing Aides to assist in the care of cancer patients will be graduated on April 17 at the annual meeting of the Field Army of the New York City Cancer Committee.

Subscription warrants entitling holders of common stock of the Food Machinery Corporation to purchase 107,010 additional shares of the Corporation's $10 par value common stock became effective yesterday.

ALBANY, April 6--Governor Dewey with a sharp memorandum vetoed today a bill which would have permitted the sale of liquor during the time of voting on primary day. The measure was sponsored by Senator William N. Conrad of Queens.

Thomas, USNR, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison C. Thomas of Port Washington, L.I. Miss Quackenbos was graduated from Wells College and is a senior at Barnard College. A labor union took the unusual step yesterday of expelling from its ranks six members whom a union trial committee found guilty of slowing down production of 40mm. shells in a Long Island City war plant. Loss of their membership means loss of their jobs, in view of the union's closed-shop contract.

WASHINGTON, April 6--The United States will support the Dumbarton Oaks proposals as a "basis for discussion" at the United Nations Security Conference in San Francisco, but will reserve the right to offer any amendments to those proposals that it chooses, Secretary Stettinius asserted today. This country will support the same right for other nations, he said.

Each received a certificate of proficiency and was assured of ultimate honorable discharge with full GI rights if he avoids further trouble.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 6--Upon the conclusion today of a five-day secret conference of leading British officials in all the Middle East countries, it was assumed, in the absence of any communique, that the conference, presided over by Sir Edward Grigg, Resident Minister in the Middle East, covered the whole field of British financial and economic policy in this region.

SEATTLE, April 6 (AP)--The last B-17 Flying Fortress built by Boeing, after nearly ten years' output of the plane, will roll out here tomorrow in ceremonies marking conversion to the manufacture of B-29 Superfortresses. All Boeing plants here, in Western Washington, Vancouver, B.C., and at Wichita, Kans., will produce B-29s.
